factoid: Dólokhov addressed Hercules and said, "You have a try," while turning to Pierre.
Pierre seized the crossbeam.
Pierre tugged the oak frame out.
Pierre wrenched the oak frame out with a crash.
Dólokhov said, "Take it right out."
Dólokhov said, "They'll think I'm holding on."
Anatole asked whether the Englishman was bragging.
Anatole asked whether it was all right.
Pierre said, "First-rate."
Pierre looked at Dólokhov.
Dólokhov was approaching the window with a bottle of rum in his hand.
The light of the sky, the dawn merging with the afterglow of sunset, was visible from the window.
Dólokhov jumped onto the window sill while holding a bottle of rum.
Dólokhov cried "Listen!"
Dólokhov was standing there.
Dólokhov addressed those in the room.
Everyone in the room was silent.
Dólokhov spoke French that the Englishman might understand.
Dólokhov's French was not very good.
Dólokhov offered a bet of fifty imperials to the Englishman.
Dólokhov asked the Englishman if he wanted to make the bet a hundred imperials.
The Englishman replied that he would bet fifty imperials.
Dólokhov stated his wager: he would drink a whole bottle of rum without taking it from his mouth.
Dólokhov stated his wager: he would sit outside the window on this spot.
Dólokhov stated his wager: he would not hold on to anything.
Dólokhov asked the Englishman if the wager was right.
The Englishman agreed that the wager was right.
Anatole turned to the Englishman.
Anatole took the Englishman by a button of his coat.
Anatole looked down at the Englishman.
Anatole began repeating the terms of the wager in English.
Dólokhov cried "Wait!" while hammering with the bottle on the window sill.
Dólokhov addressed Kurágin saying, "Wait a bit, Kurágin."
Dólokhov addressed Kurágin saying, "Listen!"
Dólokhov addressed Kurágin saying, "If anyone else does the same, I will pay him a hundred imperials."
Dólokhov addressed Kurágin asking if he understood.
The Englishman nodded, but did not indicate whether he intended to accept the challenge.
Anatole held onto the Englishman.
Anatole nodded to show understanding.
Anatole continued translating Dólokhov's words into English.
A thin young hussar of the Life Guards climbed onto the window sill.
The hussar leaned over.
The hussar looked down.
The hussar had been losing that evening.
The hussar muttered, "Oh! Oh! Oh!"
The hussar looked down at the stones of the pavement.
Dólokhov shouted "Shut up!"
Dólokhov pushed the hussar away from the window.
The hussar jumped back into the room.
The hussar tripped over his spurs.
Dólokhov placed the bottle on the window sill for easy reach.
Dólokhov climbed carefully and slowly through the window and lowered his legs.
Dólokhov pressed against both sides of the window.
Dólokhov adjusted himself on his seat.
Dólokhov lowered his hands.
Dólokhov moved slightly to the right.
Dólokhov moved slightly to the left.
Dólokhov took up the bottle.
Anatole brought two candles.
Anatole placed the candles on the window sill.
It was already quite light.
Dólokhov's back in his white shirt was lit from both sides.
Dólokhov's curly head was lit from both sides.
Everyone crowded to the window.
The Englishman was in front.
Pierre stood smiling but remained silent.
An older man pushed forward.
An older man had a scared and angry look.
An older man wanted to seize Dólokhov's shirt.
The older man said, "I say, this is folly! He’ll be killed."
Anatole stopped the older man.
Anatole told the older man not to touch Dólokhov.
Anatole warned that it would startle Dólokhov.
Anatole warned that it would cause Dólokhov to be killed.
Anatole asked what then.
Dólokhov turned around.
Dólokhov was holding on with both hands.
Dólokhov arranged himself on his seat.
Dólokhov said, "If anyone comes meddling again, I will throw him down there."
Dólokhov said, "Now then!"
